technical-data.invention-title: SYSTEM UND VERFAHREN ZUR ÜBERWACHUNG VON KRAFTSTOFFVERLAGERUNG
FUEL TRANSFER MONITORING SYSTEM AND METHOD
SYSTÈME ET PROCÉDÉ DE SURVEILLANCE DE TRANSFERT DE CARBURANT

description.p: In a relatively large fuel system having more than one individual fuel tank for providing fuel to one or more engines, such as an aircraft fuel system, it is common practice to transfer fuel from one fuel tank to one or more other fuel tanks whilst the fuel system is in use. In an aircraft fuel system this is done not only to ensure that each of the aircraft engines has fuel available at all times but to also ensure that the changing weight distribution of the aircraft as the fuel is consumed is maintained within certain limits.

In an aircraft fuel system the transfer of fuel between individual fuel tanks is ordinarily achieved by pumping the fuel from a source tank to one or more receiving tanks by opening and closing one or more fuel valves located within the fuel system. By providing one or more sensors on the fuel pumps and/or the valves it is possible to detect certain failure conditions within the fuel system, for example sensors can be provided to determine if a valve is in an open or shut condition and pressure sensors can be provided to determine if a fuel pump is operational or not.

However, there remain certain equipment failures or conditions that are not easily detectable and that cause a failure in the desired fuel transfer. For example, a valve shaft failure or blockage in the fuel transfer system are not presently easily detectable but can lead to failure of the fuel transfer.

In the event of the failure of a pumped fuel transfer on an aircraft it is normal operating practice to attempt a gravity fuel transfer in which it is attempted to transfer fuel from a source fuel tank to one or more receiving fuel tanks, where the source fuel tank is orientated above the receiving tanks within the fuel system at that time. For example, in some aircraft in addition to the fuel tanks located within the main aircraft wings an additional fuel tank, often termed the trim tank, is located within the horizontal stabilizers at the rear of the aircraft. Under normal flying conditions the trim tank is above at least some of the wing tanks. Consequently, provided the aircraft is in a suitable attitude then fuel can be fed under the effect of gravity from the trim tank to one or more of the wing tanks. Additionally, the outer wing tanks of an aircraft are often situated above the inner wing tanks when the aircraft is in a level flight attitude and consequently fuel can be transferred by gravity from the outer tanks to the inner wing tanks.

Whilst the aircraft flight crew generally have one or more instrument displays available to them informing them of the quantity of fuel held within any one of the individual fuel tanks, the rate at which the fuel quantity will change, i.e. the flow rate, during a fuel transfer may be relatively low, for example of the order of 3 to 20 tonnes an hour for a gravity transfer or 15 to 35 tonnes an hour for a pumped transfer. Consequently, even if the fuel transfer is progressing normally the flight crew are required to monitor the fuel quantity indicators over a relatively prolonged period of time to determine if the fuel transfer is proceeding at the expected rate. Often the flight crew need to review and monitor other instruments at the same time and it is therefore quite plausible that the fuel transfer is not monitored correctly by the flight crew. Additionally, the operation of the fuel system on the aircraft is typically arranged such that a fuel transfer may be instigated automatically by the aircraft control systems, in which case the flight crew might not be aware of the need to monitor the fuel transfer rate.

EP0385046 describes a system for monitoring the transfer of fuel from an auxiliary fuel tank to a main fuel tank by checking the fuel pressure in a fuel transfer line between the auxiliary fuel tank and the main fuel tank and measuring the rate of change of fuel level within the auxiliary tank.

According to a first aspect of the present invention there is provided a method of automatically monitoring a fuel transfer in an aircraft fuel system, the aircraft fuel system including a plurality of fuel tanks, the method comprising identifying a fuel transfer command to transfer fuel from a first one of the plurality of fuel tanks to a further one or more of the plurality of fuel tanks, monitoring the rate of change of fuel quantity in the first fuel tank and if the rate of change of fuel quantity is less than a flow rate threshold value then determining the fuel quantity in the first tank and comparing the quantity to a fuel quantity threshold value corresponding to an expected quantity of fuel remaining in the first fuel tank after the commanded fuel transfer is normally expected to have stopped, whereby if the fuel quantity in the first tank is greater than the fuel quantity threshold value then declaring that the fuel transfer has failed.
In the event of a fuel transfer failure, the fuel remaining in the first fuel tank may be declared unusable.
Additionally, if the fuel quantity in the first tank is less than the expected value then the method may further comprise declaring that the fuel transfer is complete.

Additionally or alternatively, the threshold value of the rate of change of fuel quantity may be less than an expected rate of change of fuel quantity during the commanded fuel transfer between the first and further fuel tanks. Additionally, the threshold value is preferably within the range of 50 to 1000 Kg of fuel per hour. The threshold value is advantageously significantly less than that expected for a normal gravity assisted fuel transfer.
The fuel transfer command may be generated either manually or automatically.

According to a further aspect of the present invention there is provided a fuel monitoring system for automatically monitoring a fuel transfer in an aircraft fuel system, the fuel system including a plurality of fuel tanks, the fuel monitoring system comprising a fuel quantity sensor arranged to measure the quantity of fuel in a first fuel tank and a data processor arranged to receive a fuel quantity measurement from the sensor, wherein in response to receiving a command to transfer fuel from the first fuel tank to one or more further fuel tanks the data processor is arranged to determine the rate of change of fuel quantity in the first tank from the received fuel quantity measurement and if the rate of change of fuel quantity is less than a flow rate threshold value and the received fuel quantity measurement is greater than a fuel quantity threshold value corresponding to an expected quantity of fuel remaining in the first fuel tank after the commanded fuel transfer is normally expected to have stopped then the data processor is further arranged to provide an output indicating that the commanded fuel transfer has failed. If the received fuel quantity measurement is less than the expected value then the data processor may be arranged to provide an output indicating that the commanded fuel transfer is complete.

In the event of a declared fuel transfer failure, the data processor may be further arranged to provide an output indicating that the remaining fuel in the first tank given by the received fuel quantity measurement is unusable.

Additionally or alternatively, the threshold value of the rate of change of fuel quantity may be less than an expected rate of change of fuel quantity for the commanded fuel transfer between the first and further tanks.
Additionally, the threshold value may be within the range of 50 to 1000 Kg per hour.
Additionally or alternatively the fuel transfer command may be generated either manually or automatically.

b.u: Detailed Description of Embodiments of the Invention

description.p: Figure 1 schematically illustrates a conventional aircraft and the common location of the fuel tanks within the aircraft fuel system. Conventionally, each wing of the aircraft includes a number of separate fuel tanks. In the example illustrated each wing has three tanks located within it, an outer tank 2 located towards the wing tip, a mid-tank 4 located in the central section of the wing, and an inner tank 6 located in the wing adjacent to the aircraft fuselage. Also illustrated is a trim tank 8 located within the horizontal stabilizers of the aircraft. When the aircraft is flying in a level attitude the outer wing tanks 2 are located above the mid-tanks 4, which are in turn located above the inner wing tanks 6 due to the upward sweep of the wing from the fuselage towards the wing tip. Also the trim tank 8 is typically above at least the inner wing tanks 6. Consequently, in normal circumstances it should be possible to transfer fuel by gravity alone from either the outer wing tanks 2, the mid-tanks 4 or the trim tank 8 to the inner wing tanks 6. For the sake of completeness, each engine of the aircraft typically has an associated feed tank that is itself interconnected to one or more of the main fuel tanks. These are not shown in Figure 1.

Figure 2 schematically illustrates part of an aircraft fuel system and a fuel transfer monitoring system according to an embodiment of the present invention. In the illustrated example a source tank 10 is taken to be located physically higher than two receiving tanks 12 within the aircraft fuel system. The source tank 10 includes a fuel quantity sensor 14 that is arranged to provide an output signal indicative of the quantity of fuel within the source tank. The fuel quantity sensor 14 may be any suitable sensor already known to the person skilled in the art. The output from the first fuel quantity sensor 14 within the source tank 10 is provided to a data processor 16. The data processor 16 is preferably connected to a display 18, or other suitable output, visible by the aircraft flight crew and one or more further data processors. Under normal operating conditions when it is desired to transfer fuel from the source tank 10 to the receiving tanks 12 a fuel pump 22, typically located within the source tank 10 is operated, in conjunction with a fuel valve 24 located within a fuel transfer line 26 connecting the fuel tanks, to pump the desired quantity of fuel from the source tank 10 to the receiving tanks 12. In the event of a pumped transfer not being possible, due to a failure of the fuel pump for example, a gravity fuel transfer will generally be requested, either automatically by the aircraft control systems or manually by the aircraft flight crew. To accomplish a gravity fuel transfer the valve 24 controlling the flow of fuel between the source tank 10 and receiving tanks 12 will be set to the open position to allow fuel to drain under the action of gravity from the source tank 10 to the receiving tanks. The fuel transfer monitoring system of embodiments of the present invention may be used to monitor the progress of either a pumped fuel transfer or a gravity fuel transfer.

Figure 3 illustrates the method of operation of a fuel transfer monitoring system in accordance with an embodiment of the present invention in the form of a flow chart. The fuel transfer monitoring is initiated in response to a fuel transfer command 30 being issued, which may be generated automatically or manually. Following the identification of the fuel transfer command the fuel quantity value 32 of the fuel in the source fuel tank 10 is monitored, the fuel quantity being provided by the fuel quantity sensor 14 within the source tank, and from this a value for the flow rate 34, or rate of change of fuel quantity, over a given period of time is calculated. The calculated flow rate 34 is compared with a predetermined flow rate threshold 36 to determine if the calculated flow rate is less than the flow rate threshold value. If the outcome of this comparison 38 is that the calculated flow rate is not less than the threshold value then the calculated flow rate of fuel from the source tank 10 is updated 34. If the outcome of the comparison 38 is that the flow rate from the first tank 10 is below the flow rate threshold value 36 then the method progresses to a further comparison step 40 at which the reported fuel quantity value 32 from the source fuel tank 10 is compared with a further fuel quantity threshold value corresponding to the fuel level when the commanded transfer is normally expected to stop. If the reported fuel quantity value in the source fuel tank 10 is greater than the fuel quantity threshold value then the fuel transfer is declared to have failed 42. A corresponding alert or message is provided from the data processor 16 of the fuel transfer monitoring system to the flight crew display 18 reporting that the fuel transfer has been declared to have failed. If the reported fuel quantity value remaining in the source fuel tank 10 is less than the fuel quantity threshold then the fuel transfer is declared to be complete 44, or successful, and a corresponding message may be provided by the data processor to the flight crew display 18 to notify the flight crew that the fuel transfer is complete.

In preferred embodiments the flow rate threshold value is set to be substantially less than the flow rate that would be expected for a gravity fuel transfer between the respective fuel tanks. Under ordinary conditions the expected fuel flow rate for a gravity transfer is in the range of 3 to 20 tonnes of fuel per hour. In embodiments of the present invention preferred values for the flow rate threshold value are, for example, between three and five times less than this, for example in the range of 50 to 1000 Kg of fuel per hour. For example, in a particular embodiment of the present invention the flow rate threshold may be 100 Kg of fuel per hour.

The fuel quantity threshold value used in the second comparison 40 may be predetermined as a function of the fuel system and design, which in turn will dictate the expected remaining amount of fuel likely in any given fuel tank after a fuel transfer.

Embodiments of the present invention therefore provide a fuel transfer monitoring system and method of monitoring a fuel transfer in a fuel system that is capable of determining when a fuel transfer is either complete or has failed without requiring any human intervention.

claim.claim-text: Verfahren zum automatischen Überwachen einer Kraftstoffübertragung in einem Flugzeugkraftstoffsystem, wobei das Flugzeugkraftstoffsystem eine Vielzahl von Kraftstofftanks (10, 12) enthält, wobei das Verfahren das Identifizierten eines Kraftstoffübertragungsbefehls (30) zum Übertragen von Kraftstoff aus einem Ersten (10) aus der Vielzahl von Kraftstofftanks zu einem Weiteren oder mehreren aus der Vielzahl von Kraftstofftanks und das Überwachen der Geschwindigkeit der Änderung (34) der Kraftstoffmenge im ersten Kraftstofftank (10) umfasst, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass das Verfahren, wenn die Geschwindigkeit der Änderung der Kraftstoffmenge (34) kleiner ist als ein Strömungsgeschwindigkeits-Schwellenwert (36), dann das Bestimmen der Kraftstoffmenge (32) im ersten Kraftstofftank umfasst, ferner das Vergleichen (40) der Menge mit einem Kraftstoffmengen-Schwellenwert, der einer erwarteten Menge an Kraftstoff entspricht, die im ersten Kraftstofftank verbleibt, nachdem die befohlene Kraftstoffübertragung normalerweise voraussichtlich gestoppt ist, wodurch deklariert wird, dass die Kraftstoffübertragung fehlgeschlagen ist (42), wenn die Kraftstoffmenge im ersten Kraftstofftank größer als der Kraftstoffmengen-Schwellenwert ist.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, bei dem die im ersten Kraftstofftank (10) verbleibende Menge an Kraftstoff anschließend als unbrauchbar deklariert wird.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, bei dem, wenn die Kraftstoffmenge im ersten Tank (10) kleiner ist als die erwartete Menge, dann deklariert wird, dass die Kraftstoffübertragung abgeschlossen ist (44).

Verfahren nach einem der vorherigen Ansprüche, bei dem der Strömungsgeschwindigkeits-Schwellenwert kleiner als eine erwartete Geschwindigkeit der Änderung der Kraftstoffmenge während der befohlenen Kraftstoffübertragung zwischen dem ersten und den weiteren Kraftstofftanks ist.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 4, bei dem der Strömungsgeschwindigkeits-Schwellenwert innerhalb des Bereichs von 50-1000 Kg Kraftstoff pro Stunde liegt.
Verfahren nach einem der vorherigen Ansprüche, bei dem der Kraftstoffübertragungsbefehl entweder manuell oder automatisch generiert wird.
Verfahren nach einem der vorherigen Ansprüche, bei dem die befohlene Kraftstoffübertragung entweder eine Pumpübertragung oder eine Schwerkraftübertragung ist.

Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem zum automatischen Überwachen einer Kraftstoffübertragung in einem Flugzeugkraftstoffsystem, wobei das Kraftstoffsystem eine Vielzahl von Kraftstofftanks (10, 12) enthält, wobei das Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem einen Kraftstoffmengensensor (14) zum Messen der Menge an Kraftstoff in einem ersten Kraftstofftank (10) und einen Datenprozessor (16) zur Aufnahme einer Kraftstoffmengenmessung (32) vom Sensor (14) umfasst, wobei der Datenprozessor (16) in Erwiderung auf den Empfang eines Befehls (30), Kraftstoff vom ersten Kraftstofftank (10) zu einem oder mehreren weiteren Kraftstofftanks (12) zu übertragen, aus der aufgenommenen Kraftstoffmengenmessung (32) die Geschwindigkeit der Änderung der Kraftstoffmenge (34) im ersten Kraftstofftank (10) bestimmt, und dadurch gekennzeichnet ist, dass der Datenprozessor (16), wenn die Geschwindigkeit der Änderung der Kraftstoffmenge (34) kleiner als ein Strömungsgeschwindigkeits-Schwellenwert (36) ist und die aufgenommene Kraftstoffmengenmessung (32) größer als ein Kraftstoffmengen-Schwellenwert ist, der einer erwarteten Menge an Kraftstoff entspricht, die im ersten Kraftstofftank verbleibt, nachdem die befohlene Kraftstoffübertragung normalerweise voraussichtlich gestoppt ist, dann eine Ausgabe bereitstellt, die anzeigt, dass die befohlene Kraftstoffübertragung fehlgeschlagen ist (42).

Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem nach Anspruch 8, bei dem, wenn die aufgenommene Kraftstoffmengenmessung kleiner ist als die erwartete Menge, der Datenprozessor (16) eine Ausgabe bereitstellt, die anzeigt, dass die befohlene Kraftstoffübertragung abgeschlossen ist (44).

Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem nach Anspruch 8, bei dem der Datenprozessor (16) ferner eine Ausgabe bereitstellt, die anzeigt, dass der durch die aufgenommene Kraftstoffmengenmessung verbleibende Kraftstoff im ersten Tank (10) unbrauchbar ist.

Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem nach einem der Ansprüche 8 bis 10, bei dem der Strömungsgeschwindigkeits-Schwellenwert kleiner als eine erwartete Geschwindigkeit der Änderung der Kraftstoffmenge während der befohlenen Kraftstoffübertragung zwischen dem ersten (10) und den weiteren (12) Kraftstofftanks ist.
Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem nach Anspruch 11, bei dem der Strömungsgeschwindigkeits-Schwellenwert innerhalb des Bereichs von 50-1000 Kg Kraftstoff pro Stunde liegt.
Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem nach einem der Ansprüche 8 bis 12, bei dem der Kraftstoffübertragungsbefehl entweder manuell oder automatisch generiert wird.
Kraftstoffüberwachungssystem nach einem der Ansprüche 8 bis 13, bei dem die befohlene Kraftstoffübertragung entweder eine Pumpübertragung oder eine Schwerkraftübertragung ist.

A method of automatically monitoring a fuel transfer in an aircraft fuel system, the aircraft fuel system including a plurality of fuel tanks (10, 12), the method comprising identifying a fuel transfer command (30) to transfer fuel from a first one (10) of the plurality of fuel tanks to a further one or more (12) of the plurality of fuel tanks, monitoring the rate of change (34) of fuel quantity in the first fuel tank (10), characterised in that if the rate of change of fuel quantity (34) is less than a flow rate threshold value (36) the method then comprises determining the fuel quantity (32) in the first fuel tank and comparing (40) the quantity to a fuel quantity threshold value corresponding to an expected quantity of fuel remaining in the first fuel tank after the commanded fuel transfer is normally expected to have stopped, whereby if the fuel quantity in the first tank is greater than the fuel quantity threshold value then declaring that the fuel transfer has failed (42).
The method of claim 1, wherein the quantity of fuel remaining in the first fuel tank (10) is subsequently declared unusable.
The method of claim 1, whereby if the fuel quantity in the first tank (10) is less than the expected quantity then declaring that the fuel transfer is complete (44).

The method of any preceding claim, whereby the flow rate threshold value is less than an expected rate of change of fuel quantity during the commanded fuel transfer between the first and further fuel tanks.
The method of claim 4, whereby the flow rate threshold value is within the range of 50-1000 Kg of fuel per hour.
The method of any preceding claim, whereby the fuel transfer command is generated either manually or automatically.
The method of any preceding claim, whereby the commanded fuel transfer is either a pumped transfer or a gravity transfer.

A fuel monitoring system for automatically monitoring a fuel transfer in an aircraft fuel system, the fuel system including a plurality of fuel tanks (10, 12), the fuel monitoring system comprising a fuel quantity sensor (14) arranged to measure the quantity of fuel in a first fuel tank (10) and a data processor (16) arranged to receive a fuel quantity measurement (32) from the sensor (14), wherein in response to receiving a command (30) to transfer fuel from the first fuel tank (10) to one or more further fuel tanks (12) the data processor (16) is arranged to determine the rate of change of fuel quantity (34) in the first tank (10) from the received fuel quantity measurement and characterised in that if the rate of change of fuel quantity (34) is less than a flow rate threshold value (36) and the received fuel quantity measurement (32) is greater than a fuel quantity threshold value corresponding to an expected quantity of fuel remaining in the first fuel tank after the commanded fuel transfer is normally expected to have stopped then the data processor (16) is further arranged to provide an output indicating that the commanded fuel transfer has failed (42).

The fuel monitoring system of claim 8, wherein if the received fuel quantity measurement is less than the expected quantity the data processor (16) is arranged to provide an output indicating that the commanded fuel transfer is complete (44).

The fuel monitoring system of claim 8, wherein the data processor (16) is further arranged to provide an output indicating that the remaining fuel in the first tank (10) given by the received fuel quantity measurement is unusable.

The fuel monitoring system of any one of claims 8 to 10, wherein the flow rate threshold value is less than an expected rate of change of fuel quantity during the commanded fuel transfer between the first (10) and further (12) tanks.
The fuel monitoring system of claim 11, wherein the flow rate threshold value is within the range of 50-1000 Kg per hour.
The fuel monitoring system of any one of claims 8 to 12, wherein the fuel transfer command is generated either manually or automatically.
The fuel monitoring system of any one of claims 8 to 13, wherein the commanded fuel transfer is either a pumped transfer or a gravity transfer.

Procédé de surveillance automatique d'un transfert de carburant dans le circuit carburant d'un avion, le circuit carburant de l'avion comprenant une pluralité de réservoirs de carburant (10, 12), le procédé comprenant l'identification d'une commande de transfert de carburant (30) pour transférer du carburant d'un premier (10) de la pluralité de réservoirs de carburant à un ou plusieurs autres (12) de la pluralité de réservoirs de carburant, la surveillance du taux de changement (34) de la quantité de carburant dans le premier réservoir de carburant (10), caractérisé en ce que si le taux de changement de la quantité de carburant (34) est inférieur à une valeur seuil de débit (36), le procédé comprend alors la détermination de la quantité de carburant (32) dans le premier réservoir de carburant et la comparaison (40) de ladite quantité à une valeur seuil de quantité de carburant correspondant à une quantité prévue de carburant restant dans le premier réservoir de carburant après que le transfert de carburant commandé est normalement censé avoir pris fin, moyennant quoi si la quantité de carburant dans le premier réservoir est supérieure à la valeur seuil de quantité de carburant, le transfert de carburant est alors déclaré comme ayant échoué (42).
Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel la quantité de carburant restant dans le premier réservoir de carburant (10) est consécutivement déclarée inutilisable.
Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel si la quantité de carburant dans le premier réservoir (10) est inférieure à la valeur prévue, le transfert de carburant est alors déclaré terminé (44).

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel la valeur seuil de débit est inférieure à un taux de changement prévu de la quantité de carburant pendant le transfert de carburant commandé entre le premier réservoir de carburant et les autres.
Procédé selon la revendication 4, dans lequel la valeur seuil de débit se situe dans une plage de 50 à 1 000 Kg de carburant par heure.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel la commande de transfert de carburant est délivrée manuellement ou automatiquement.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel le transfert de carburant commandé est un transfert par pompage ou un transfert par gravité.

Système de surveillance de carburant permettant de surveiller automatiquement un transfert de carburant dans le circuit carburant d'un avion, le circuit carburant comprenant une pluralité de réservoirs de carburant (10, 12), le système de surveillance de carburant comprenant un capteur de quantité de carburant (14) conçu pour mesurer la quantité de carburant dans un premier réservoir de carburant (10) et un processeur de données (16) conçu pour recevoir une mesure de quantité de carburant (32) du capteur (14), dans lequel en réponse à la réception d'une commande (30) de transfert de carburant du premier réservoir de carburant (10) à un ou plusieurs autres réservoirs de carburant (12), le processeur de données (16) est conçu pour déterminer le taux de changement de la quantité de carburant (34) dans le premier réservoir (10) à partir de la mesure de la quantité de carburant reçue et caractérisé en ce que si le taux de changement de la quantité de carburant (34) est inférieur à une valeur seuil de débit (36) et la mesure de la quantité de carburant reçue (32) est supérieure à une valeur seuil de quantité de carburant correspondant à une quantité prévue de carburant restant dans le premier réservoir de carburant après que le transfert de carburant commandé est normalement censé avoir pris fin, le processeur de données (16) est conçu en outre pour délivrer un résultat indiquant que le transfert de carburant commandé a échoué (42).

Système de surveillance de carburant selon la revendication 8, dans lequel si la mesure de la quantité de carburant reçue est inférieure à la quantité prévue, le processeur de données (16) est conçu pour délivrer un résultat indiquant que le transfert de carburant commandé est terminé (44).

Système de surveillance de carburant selon la revendication 8, dans lequel le processeur de données (16) est conçu en outre pour délivrer un résultat indiquant que le carburant restant dans le premier réservoir (10) donné par la mesure de la quantité de carburant reçue est inutilisable.

Système de surveillance de carburant selon l'une quelconque des revendications 8 à 10, dans lequel la valeur seuil de débit est inférieure à un taux de changement prévu de la quantité de carburant pendant le transfert de carburant commandé entre le premier réservoir (10) et les autres (12).
Système de surveillance de carburant selon la revendication 11, dans lequel la valeur seuil de débit se situe dans une plage de 50 à 1 000 Kg par heure.
